DataElement.preferredName: Procedure Domain Reported Name of Procedure Diagnostic Assessment Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The procedure name that describes the type of assessment method used for diagnosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Procedure Domain Reported Name of Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to procedure._The literal identifier of the procedure.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to procedure.

Concepts.definition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to procedure.

Property.preferredDefinition: The literal identifier of the procedure.

Concepts.definition: The literal identifier of the procedure.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 7-20-20 tmt released. Created as part of the CDISC mapping task_ghd_08.23.18

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Characteristic or indicative of a condition._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Endoscopic examination of the larynx.

Concepts.definition: Endoscopic examination of the larynx.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (lap-a-RAHS-ko-pee) The insertion of a thin, lighted tube (called a laparoscope) through the abdominal wall to inspect the inside of the abdomen and remove tissue samples.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure during which a laparoscope is inserted into the abdomen to view the abdominopelvic contents for diagnostic and/or therapeutic purposes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: LAPAROTOMY

Concepts.definition: Creation of a surgical opening into the abdominal cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of tissue from the liver for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Removal of tissue from the liver for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Longitudinal Relaxation Time Magnetic Resonance Imaging

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Longitudinal Relaxation Time Magnetic Resonance Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The time it takes for the net nuclear spin in the plane that is parallel to the magnetic field of a spectrometer to return to its equilibrium value.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: The time it takes for the net nuclear spin in the plane that is parallel to the magnetic field of a spectrometer to return to its equilibrium value.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An x-ray image of the lymphatic system using a radiopaque imaging agent.

Concepts.definition: An x-ray image of the lymphatic system using a radiopaque imaging agent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low voltage X-ray photograph of the breast generally done to detect breast cancer. This method is also valuable in diagnosis of benign abnormal conditions of the breast such as fibroadenoma, mastitis, abscess, and cysts.

Concepts.definition: A low voltage X-ray photograph of the breast generally done to detect breast cancer. This method is also valuable in diagnosis of benign abnormal conditions of the breast such as fibroadenoma, mastitis, abscess, and cysts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An analytical technique wherein ions are separate according to their ratio of charge to mass. From the mass spectrum produced, the atomic weight of the particle can be deduced.

Concepts.definition: An analytical technique wherein ions are separated according to their ratio of charge to mass. From the mass spectrum produced, the atomic weight of the particle can be deduced.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the breast.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the breast.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Techniques for studying or analyzing the genetic composition and mechanisms of living organisms at the molecular level. May refer to the understanding and manipulation of genes (DNA).

Concepts.definition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to or produced by or consisting of molecules.: A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug.

Concepts.definition: Relating to or produced by or consisting of molecules.
A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

Concepts.definition: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image of blood vessels constructed using magnetic resonance imaging.

Concepts.definition: An image of blood vessels constructed using magnetic resonance imaging.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.: A diffusion MRI technique in which diffusion-sensitizing gradients are applied to the imaging sequence.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
A diffusion MRI technique in which diffusion-sensitizing gradients are applied to the imaging sequence.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multi-gated acquisition (MUGA) scan and a form of radionuclide imaging that provides a comprehensive look at blood flow and the function of the lower chambers of the heart ventricles.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic test used to evaluate the pumping function of the heart's ventricles. A radioactive tracer is injected into a vein and a gamma camera detects the radiation released by the tracer, with image acquisition triggered (gated) at different points of the cardiac cycle.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  WZhang, 02/23/2015

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.: The appearance of objects (or light sources) described in terms of a person's perception of their hue and lightness (or brightness) and saturation.: A technique for counting, examining and sorting microscopic particles suspended in a stream of fluid.

Concepts.definition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.
The appearance of objects (or light sources) described in terms of a person's perception of their hue and lightness (or brightness) and saturation.
A technique for counting, examining and sorting microscopic particles suspended in a stream of fluid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An autoantibody directed against myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG). It is associated with active demyelination in peripheral neuropathy and is detected in about 50% of patients with IgM paraproteinemia and may occur in some patients with multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic polyneuropathy, or myasthenia gravis.

Concepts.definition: An autoantibody directed against myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG). It is associated with active demyelination in peripheral neuropathy and is detected in about 50% of patients with IgM paraproteinemia and may occur in some patients with multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic polyneuropathy, or myasthenia gravis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Technologies that facilitate the rapid determination of the DNA sequence of large numbers of strands or segments of DNA.

Concepts.definition: Technologies that facilitate the rapid determination of the nucleotide sequence of large numbers of strands or segments of DNA or RNA.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A set of proprietary genomic profiling techniques that utilize next generation sequencing. FoundationOne CDX is optimized for PPFE samples from solid tumors; FoundationOne Liquid is optimized for peripheral whole blood, targeting solid tumors; FoundationOne Heme is optimized for leukemias, lymphomas, sarcomas, and solid tumors using RNA sequencing on samples obtained from FFPE, peripheral whole blood, or bone marrow aspirate.

Concepts.definition: A set of proprietary genomic profiling techniques that utilize next generation sequencing. FoundationOne CDX is optimized for PPFE samples from solid tumors; FoundationOne Liquid is optimized for peripheral whole blood, targeting solid tumors; FoundationOne Heme is optimized for leukemias, lymphomas, sarcomas, and solid tumors using RNA sequencing on samples obtained from FFPE, peripheral whole blood, or bone marrow aspirate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary genomic profiling system that utilizes a proprietary next generation Digital Sequencing technology on samples obtain from blood. It is designed to detect alterations in over 70 genes relevant to multiple solid tumor types.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary genomic profiling system that utilizes a proprietary next generation Digital Sequencing technology on samples obtain from blood. It is designed to detect alterations in over 70 genes relevant to multiple solid tumor types.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: NOT DONE

Concepts.definition: No value exists.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.: Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Associated concept to VM for TCGA. mc 11/9/12 - reversed concept order to match the semantics of this phrase which is "other" with "specify" as a qualifier/modifier - DW 12-30-2015

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.: Having been established or verified.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
Having been established or verified.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The number of pitted erythrocytes in a blood sample, expressed as a percentage. It is used as an indicator of splenic function.

Concepts.definition: The number of pitted erythrocytes in a blood sample, expressed as a percentage. It is used as an indicator of splenic function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

Concepts.definition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 7-20-20 TMT updated concept with NCIt definition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to or occurring during the period immediately before a surgical operation.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: Relating to or occurring during the period immediately before a surgical operation.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to reduce the risk of developing breast cancer by removing one or both breasts before disease develops.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to reduce the risk of developing breast cancer by removing one or both breasts before disease develops.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added concept and corrected typo in Long Name. mc 7/15/19

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Alternate isoforms of the single-chain 261-aa 30-kD Kallikrein 3 (Prostate Specific Antigen) glycoprotein precursor are encoded by human KLK3 Gene (Kallikrein Family). Frameshifted isoform 2 has a shorter distinct C-terminus. A serine protease in seminal plasma, PSA may function in liquefaction of seminal coagulum by (preferential Tyr-X) cleavage of seminal vesicle protein. Kallikrein proteases have diverse functions. Mounting evidence implicates kallikreins in carcinogenesis; some have potential as cancer biomarkers. The serum level of PSA is useful in diagnosis and monitoring of prostatic carcinoma. (from LocusLink, Swiss-Prot, OMIM, and NCI)

Concepts.definition: Prostate-specific antigen (261 aa, ~29 kDa) is encoded by the human KLK3 gene. This protein plays a role in both proteolysis and seminal fluid liquefaction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of penetrating energy waves to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation._Having been established or verified._Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Concepts.definition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of penetrating energy waves to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.
Having been established or verified.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.: Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

Concepts.definition: An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.
Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is guided into the right heart, where pressures may be measured and radiocontrast material may be injected to visualize blood flow in and around the right heart.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is guided into the right heart, where pressures may be measured and radiocontrast material may be injected to visualize blood flow in and around the right heart.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the in vitro reactions and properties of immune sera, particularly, the concept refers to the use of such reactions to measure serum titers of antibody against infectious and non-infectious agents (serologic tests), to the clinical correlations of the antibody titer, and to the use of serologic reactions to detect antigens.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the in vitro reactions and properties of immune sera, particularly, the concept refers to the use of such reactions to measure serum titers of antibody against infectious and non-infectious agents (serologic tests), to the clinical correlations of the antibody titer, and to the use of serologic reactions to detect antigens.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.: The determination of the amount of ferritin present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.
The determination of the amount of ferritin present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for virus culture and detection in which a virus sample is mixed with a susceptible cell type and then centrifuged into a single layer of cells. Following a short incubation, viral growth is determined using immunological detection techniques.

Concepts.definition: A method for virus culture and detection in which a virus sample is mixed with a susceptible cell type and then centrifuged into a single layer of cells. Following a short incubation, viral growth is determined using immunological detection techniques.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for assessing prognosis for patients with chronic myeloid leukemia. The numerical value is calculated at diagnosis from the percentage of blast cells in peripheral blood, the platelet count, the spleen size, and the age of the patient.

Concepts.definition: A method for assessing prognosis for patients with chronic myeloid leukemia. The numerical value is calculated at diagnosis from the percentage of blast cells in peripheral blood, the platelet count, the spleen size, and the age of the patient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of computed tomography (CT) that uses continuous rotation of the X-ray tube and continuous transport of the patient through the scanning aperture that allows the rapid acquisition of a volume of CT data.  Advantages over conventional CT include: rapid acquisition of a large volume of data within a single breath-hold, thus minimizing respiration artifact and misregistration between slices; the ability to reconstruct images retrospectively at any level within the scanned volume; optimization of intravenous contrast enhancement due to the short scan times; improved multi-planar and 3-D reconstruction; and the potential for radiation dose reduction.  Same as helical computed tomography. (British Journal of Radiology 1994 May;67(797):436-44)

Concepts.definition: A method of computed tomography (CT) that uses continuous rotation of the X-ray tube and continuous transport of the patient through the scanning aperture that allows the rapid acquisition of a volume of CT data.  Advantages over conventional CT include: rapid acquisition of a large volume of data within a single breath-hold, thus minimizing respiration artifact and misregistration between slices; the ability to reconstruct images retrospectively at any level within the scanned volume; optimization of intravenous contrast enhancement due to the short scan times; improved multi-planar and 3-D reconstruction; and the potential for radiation dose reduction.  Same as helical computed tomography. (British Journal of Radiology 1994 May;67(797):436-44)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radionuclide imaging technique that is used to evaluate the size and shape of the spleen, and to detect and evaluate lesions, rupture, and hematomas.

Concepts.definition: A radionuclide imaging technique that is used to evaluate the size and shape of the spleen, and to detect and evaluate lesions, rupture, and hematomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A device designed to measure extremely weak magnetic fields. It is comprised of a Josephson junction with two superconducting loops separated by an insulating layer thin enough to allow electrons to pass through.

Concepts.definition: A device designed to measure extremely weak magnetic fields. It is comprised of a Josephson junction with two superconducting loops separated by an insulating layer thin enough to allow electrons to pass through.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Superconducting Quantum Interference Device Magnetic Resonance Imaging

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Superconducting Quantum Interference Device Magnetic Resonance Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A device designed to measure extremely weak magnetic fields. It is comprised of a Josephson junction with two superconducting loops separated by an insulating layer thin enough to allow electrons to pass through.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: A device designed to measure extremely weak magnetic fields. It is comprised of a Josephson junction with two superconducting loops separated by an insulating layer thin enough to allow electrons to pass through.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specialty in which manual or operative procedures are used in the treatment of disease, injuries, or deformities.

Concepts.definition: The branch of medical science that treats disease or injury by operative procedures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: MRI imaging based on the observed T2 relaxation time of tissues.

Concepts.definition: MRI imaging based on the observed T2 relaxation time of tissues.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.7.24 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002644. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that uses sound waves to create a video image of the prostate gland. A small, lubricated probe placed into the rectum releases sound waves, which create echoes as they enter the prostate. Prostate tumors sometimes create echoes that are different from normal prostate tissue. The echoes that bounce back are sent to a computer that translates the pattern of echoes into a picture of the prostate.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that uses sound waves to create a video image of the pelvic organs and tissues. A small, lubricated probe placed into the rectum releases sound waves, which create echoes as they enter a pelvic organ. The echoes that bounce back are sent to a computer that translates the pattern of echoes into a picture of the specific organ under examination.  This procedure is most often used to evaluate the prostate gland.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Very high frequency sound.

Concepts.definition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The property of being measured and described using two orthogonal directions.: An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.

Concepts.definition: The property of being measured and described using two orthogonal directions.
An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of, or related to, the abdomen.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: Of, or related to, the abdomen.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of, or related to, the abdomen.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Of, or related to, the abdomen.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any substance that appears foreign or potentially adverse to the body and elicits immune response.

Concepts.definition: Any substance, generally a protein, that stimulates the immune system and elicits an immune response.  Recognition by the immune system elicits either a T-lymphocyte response, recognizing processed antigens, or a B-lymphocyte response, producing antibodies that bind to unprocessed antigens.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.
A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET), a diagnostic imaging procedure.: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: A positron-emitting radiopharmaceutical containing radioactive 2-deoxy-2-[18F] fluoro-D-glucose. With similar cell uptake as glucose (high in tumor cells), fludeoxyglucose F 18 is not dephosphorylated and further metabolized. (NCI04)

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Autopsy; an examination and dissection of a dead body to determine cause of death or the changes produced by disease.

Concepts.definition: A postmortem examination of the body that includes an examination of the internal organs and structures after dissection to determine the cause of death and the nature of pathological changes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the armpit area, including the lymph nodes that are located there.: The process of cutting apart or separating tissue as, for example, in the study of anatomy or in the course of a surgical procedure.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the armpit area, including the lymph nodes that are located there.
The process of cutting apart or separating tissue as, for example, in the study of anatomy or in the course of a surgical procedure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.: A method of computed tomography (CT) that uses continuous rotation of the X-ray tube and continuous transport of the patient through the scanning aperture that allows the rapid acquisition of a volume of CT data.  Advantages over conventional CT include: rapid acquisition of a large volume of data within a single breath-hold, thus minimizing respiration artifact and misregistration between slices; the ability to reconstruct images retrospectively at any level within the scanned volume; optimization of intravenous contrast enhancement due to the short scan times; improved multi-planar and 3-D reconstruction; and the potential for radiation dose reduction.  Same as helical computed tomography. (British Journal of Radiology 1994 May;67(797):436-44)

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

A method of computed tomography (CT) that uses continuous rotation of the X-ray tube and continuous transport of the patient through the scanning aperture that allows the rapid acquisition of a volume of CT data.  Advantages over conventional CT include: rapid acquisition of a large volume of data within a single breath-hold, thus minimizing respiration artifact and misregistration between slices; the ability to reconstruct images retrospectively at any level within the scanned volume; optimization of intravenous contrast enhancement due to the short scan times; improved multi-planar and 3-D reconstruction; and the potential for radiation dose reduction.  Same as helical computed tomography. (British Journal of Radiology 1994 May;67(797):436-44)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.: A low voltage X-ray photograph of the breast generally done to detect breast cancer. This method is also valuable in diagnosis of benign abnormal conditions of the breast such as fibroadenoma, mastitis, abscess, and cysts.

Concepts.definition: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

A low voltage X-ray photograph of the breast generally done to detect breast cancer. This method is also valuable in diagnosis of benign abnormal conditions of the breast such as fibroadenoma, mastitis, abscess, and cysts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to, or performed by, both hands.: A formal or careful inspection of an object or subject.

Concepts.definition: Relating to, or performed by, both hands.
A formal or careful inspection of an object or subject.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc 4.23.19

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (as-per-AY-shun) The removal of a small sample of bone marrow (usually from the hip) through a needle for examination under a microscope.

Concepts.definition: Aspiration of immature hematopoietic elements and blood from the bone marrow.  It is done for the evaluation of hematopoietic disorders and for the evaluation of infectious diseases and cytogenetic studies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: BONE MARROW BIOPSY

Concepts.definition: A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

Concepts.definition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction.

Concepts.definition: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure in which a thin, lighted tube is inserted through the nose or mouth. NCI Concept Code C16366

Concepts.definition: Endoscopic examination of the tracheobronchial tree.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: FOLH1 wt Allele Positron Emission Tomography

ValueMeaning.preferredName: FOLH1 wt Allele Positron Emission Tomography
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Human FOLH1 wild-type allele is located in the vicinity of 11p11.2 and is approximately 62 kb in length. This allele, which encodes glutamate carboxypeptidase 2 protein, plays a role in both the uptake of folate in the intestine and the hydrolysis of N-aceylaspartylglutamate, the major neurotransmitter in the brain. This gene is overexpressed in human prostate cancer and may inhibit metastasis of this disease.: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: Human FOLH1 wild-type allele is located in the vicinity of 11p11.2 and is approximately 62 kb in length. This allele, which encodes glutamate carboxypeptidase 2 protein, plays a role in both the uptake of folate in the intestine and the hydrolysis of N-aceylaspartylglutamate, the major neurotransmitter in the brain. This gene is overexpressed in human prostate cancer and may inhibit metastasis of this disease.

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A medical device that is a combination of ruler and caliper that can measure the distance between two points. The configuration of this device permits the measurement of internal dimensions.: Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.: A physical examination is a systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion, and auscultation, aimed to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for individual's health assessment.

Concepts.definition: A medical device that is a combination of ruler and caliper that can measure the distance between two points. The configuration of this device permits the measurement of internal dimensions.
Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.

A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrophoresis procedure, in which a sample is introduced into a capillary tube and the components are separated by the application of high voltage. Due to the large surface to volume ratio, cooling is more efficient, allowing use of higher voltages.  As a result, separation occurs more quickly and sensitivity is increased. The technique allows for separation of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates.

Concepts.definition: An electrophoresis procedure, in which a sample is introduced into a capillary tube and the components are separated by the application of high voltage. Due to the large surface to volume ratio, cooling is more efficient, allowing use of higher voltages.  As a result, separation occurs more quickly and sensitivity is increased. The technique allows for separation of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A test to monitor for neurotoxicity related to CAR T therapy: orientation to year, month, city, hospital, and President; ability to name 3 specified objects; ability to write a standard sentence; ability to count backwards from 100 by 10.

Concepts.definition: A test to monitor for neurotoxicity related to CAR T therapy: orientation to year, month, city, hospital, and President; ability to name 3 specified objects; ability to write a standard sentence; ability to count backwards from 100 by 10.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Carcinoembryonic antigen. A substance that is sometimes found in an increased amount in the blood of people with certain cancers.

Concepts.definition: A cancer-specific antigen associated with both tumors and the developing fetus. The main use of this antigen is as a tumor marker, especially with respect to intestinal cancers. Production of the antigen ceases shortly before birth, but may reappear in people who develop certain types of cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any imaging procedure that uses radiation to create an image for the purpose of assisting with the execution of an intervention.

Concepts.definition: Any imaging procedure that uses radiation to create an image for the purpose of assisting with the execution of an intervention.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A highly sensitive technique for detecting and measuring antigens or antibodies in a solution; the solution is run over a surface to which immobilized antibodies specific to the substance have been attatched, and if the substance is present, it will bind to the antibody layer, and its presence is verified and visualized with an application of antibodies that have been tagged in some way. (BioTech Life Science Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: A highly sensitive technique for detecting and measuring antigens or antibodies in a solution; the solution is run over a surface to which immobilized antibodies specific to the substance have been attached, and if the substance is present, it will bind to the antibody layer, and its presence is verified and visualized with an application of antibodies that have been tagged in some way. (BioTech Life Science Dictionary)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: Pertaining to or related to the blood and blood-forming organs.: Analysis; examination and interpretation.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Pertaining to or related to the blood and blood-forming organs.

Examination and interpretation; the process of identifying an issue to be understood and addressed, modelling the issue, investigating the model results, interpreting the results, and possibly making a recommendation. The concept also refers to the examination and study of a whole in terms of the parts composing it.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.: A method of feeling with the hands during a physical examination. The health care provider touches and feels the patient's body to examine the size, consistency, texture, location and tenderness of an organ or body part.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.

A method of feeling with the hands during a physical examination. The health care provider touches and feels the patient's body to examine the size, consistency, texture, location and tenderness of an organ or body part.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Endoscopic examination of the luminal surface of the colon.

Concepts.definition: Endoscopic examination of the luminal surface of the colon.

PermissibleValues.value: MRI of the brain with orbital cuts
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Brain With Orbit Sequence Magnetic Resonance Imaging

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Brain With Orbit Sequence Magnetic Resonance Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.: A serial arrangement in which things follow in logical order or a recurrent pattern.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.

The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.
A serial arrangement in which things follow in logical order or a recurrent pattern.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to the spine or spinal cord.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to the spine or spinal cord.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.: The determination of the number of erythrocytes in a blood sample.

Concepts.definition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.
The determination of the number of erythrocytes in a biospecimen.
